title: Why is ammonium nitrate rarely written as (NH4) 2NO3? - Quora

response.answer_text: Because [math](NH_{4})_{2}NO_{3}[/math] is the INCORRECT formulation of [math]\text{ammonium nitrate}[/math]. In this scenario we would have…[[math](NH_{4})_{2}NO_{3}]^{+}[/math], a CATIONIC species… [math]\text{Ammonium nitrate}[/math] is the SALT of ammonium cation, i.e. [math]NH_{4}^{+}[/math], and nitrate anion, [math]NO_{3}^{-}[/math]. And these thus combine in a 1:1 stoichiometry to give an electrically neutral salt… And so we got [math]NH_{4}^{+}NO_{3}^{-}[/math] as the correct formulation… Note that the Lewis structure of nitrate ion is interesting in that THREE of the four atoms have formal charges…of course, resonance isomers exist… [math]O=\stackrel{+}N(-O^{-})_{2}[/math]. Is this structure consistent with the formal charge of the ion?

Because the formula given is incorrect - the ammonium cation and nitrate anion both have charges of 1 (positive for the former, negative for the latter), so the stoichiometrically balanced compound has the formula NH4NO3.
